Award.AwardTitle: I-CORPS Team: Cocoon Cam, a Wearless Smart Baby Monitor
Award.AbstractNarration:
Despite the availability of baby monitors, parents continue to check on their baby at regular intervals. Conventional video or audio based baby monitors are not able to detect vitals or identify if the baby is unwell. Parents like existing video based monitors to confirm that the baby is safe and well when awake, but the lack of body movement while the baby is sleeping leads to anxiety and repeated check on the baby. This problem recently led to the development of wearable baby monitors that can detect vitals. However, wearables are perceived detrimental to the baby's health due to radio frequency effects and possible skin allergies. The technology developed by this team involves integration of software and hardware enabling concurrent non-contact measurement of heart and respiratory rate, and temperature from a single device, day and night.

This I-Corps team will build a portable non-contact device to detect vital signs and eliminate the need for hardware to be attached or in extremely close proximity to the baby. The proposed solution is Cocoon Cam, a wearless network-connected system that consists of hardware and software sensors and provides video, audio, and vitals on a dashboard to check on those at day or night. Parents can view the dashboard on a smartphone and set personalized alerts for any of the monitored features. Parents perceive that a dependable device that could help monitor vitals is beneficial and gives peace of mind that their babies are healthy and comfortable.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project investigated the market potential of a technology for remotely and non invasively detect heart rate, respiration rate and temperature of babys.

This NSF award enabled a new team to be assembled; the team was composed by Dr. Nadir Weibel, a faculty in the Computer Science and Engineering Department at UC San Diego (PI of the project), Mr. Dennis Abremsky, the Entrepreneurial Mentor of the project, and Mr. Pavan Kumar, the student lead.

Through this award the team was able to demonstrate the market potential for the technology, dubbed CocoonCam. The interviews with hundreds of stakeholders in the general public, as well as in the healthcare setting, outlined two potential market opportunities:

(1) A recreational baby monitor that could be installed on the crib of babys who were at potential risk of Sudden Infant Death (SID), or for who parents wanted to have a constant vital sign monitor during sleep;

(2) A medical device that could be installed in the Neonatal Intensive Care Unit (NICU) of a hospital and could help detecting vital signs, and a the same time limit existing problems such as lesions on babys' skin created by current leads, false alarm due to leads being disconnected, and the impossibility of parents to stay close to their babys due to the many leads attached to them.

At the end of the award, the team pursued the opportunity outlined above and was able to secure funding for the first scenario. After further Research and Development and the securing of the right production and distribution channels, CocoonCam is now a product (http://cocooncam.com) and can be purchased online on the bigest online platforms such as Amazon.com.

The team is still investigating possibly supporting the second scenario with pilot studies running at Stanford University and UC San Diego.
